Award.AwardTitle: Revealing Exchange Interactions in Magnetic Bilayers at the Atomic Scale
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is jointly funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) and Condensed Matter Physics Program (CMP) in the Division of Materials Research (DMR).

Technical Description: This project is aimed at exploring and revealing magnetic exchange interaction mechanisms in magnetic bilayer systems down to atomic scale. It includes three research components: 1) magnetic polarizability of normally non-magnetic materials in contact with magnetic layers; 2) fundamental origins of exchange bias; and 3) effects of long-range interactions in magnetic bilayer systems. In all cases, spatial variations are of particular interest, as a function of which exchange interactions may depend strongly. Bilayer ultra-thin films are prepared using either molecular beam or pulsed laser epitaxy. Following the materials synthesis step, the bilayer systems are studied using the technique of spin-polarized scanning tunneling microscopy. Magnetic, electronic, and topographical information down to the atomic scale is obtained simultaneously from constant current images and from differential conductance data by using magnetic probe tips. Comparing to theoretical calculations, the results can provide new insights into the fundamentals of these important and technologically impactful material systems.

Non-technical Description: In order to miniaturize devices further and further, it is critical to have fundamental understanding of the underlying physics. A general phenomenon called exchange coupling is at the heart of the most advanced magnetic device technologies today. An important example is exchange bias, in which two types of thin magnetic layers - a ferromagnetic and an antiferromagnetic layer - are put into direct contact. This can result in a unique behavior called hysteresis shift and increases in a parameter called the coercivity. These effects underlie modern high-density read head technology; but despite many theories designed to explain it, its ultimate origins remain a mystery. In this project, by employing a magnetically sensitive probe technique having atomic-scale resolution, scientists aim to unravel exchange coupling effects, and hopefully to provide new insights which can have important impacts on future magnetic technologies. The project also aims to provide key educational and outreach opportunities for students ranging from K-12 through the Ph.D. level. Both undergraduate and graduate students are active participants in all phases of the project, on their way to becoming future scientists. At the same time, two new outreach activities are undertaken - one involving presentations in K-12 schools, the other involving after-school, university-campus activities for K-12 students - whose overall purpose is to inspire the children of Southeast Ohio to pursue science and engineering career paths.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF project at Ohio University was aimed at the investigation of magnetic exchange coupling in magnetic bi-layer thin films. The investigations focused on bi-layers consisting of a ferromagnetic layer in contact with an antiferromagnetic layer. The thickness of the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic layers was in the range of a few nanometers up to several hundred nanometers. These kinds of magnetically coupled bi-layers are key elements used in advanced magnetic device technologies, and yet there is a need for improved understanding of the coupling mechanisms in order to gain greater control over device properties and to make further advances.

The approach taken here was to fabricate bi-layer films using the technique of molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) followed by transfer of the samples directly into an adjoining surface analysis chamber in order to directly probe the properties of the clean bi-layer interfaces without ambient exposure. In MBE, elemental materials and layers are deposited atom by atom within an evacuated growth chamber, rendering this a very powerful deposition technique, ideal for these studies. The sample analysis consists of scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), a technique capable of imaging surfaces down to the atomic scale, and Auger electron spectroscopy (AES), a technique yielding surface chemical composition.

The studies were carried out within two independently operating, MBE/STM sample deposition and analysis systems which are each custom built. This project served as well to support the improvement and operation of these systems, thus impacting on-campus research infrastructure. It also supported the training of 6 Ph.D. students learning to operate this type of instrumentation.

Especially important in these magnetic bi-layer systems are the properties of the interfaces between the two layers. High resolution STM images of the interfaces, along with surface conductivity maps, were acquired which allowed a detailed understanding of the structural and electronic properties of the interfaces. Additionally, the interfaces were chemically characterized using AES to determine the extent of elemental intermixing, and this information was compared to surface/interface simulations resulting from theoretical calculations done by theory students from Puebla, Mexico. The bi-layer systems were also subjected to investigation using additional ex-situ techniques such as x-ray diffraction and vibrating sample magnetometry, which quantify the crystalline orientations of the bi-layers and their magnetic responses, respectively.

Particular bi-layer systems investigated include iron/manganese nitride, iron gallium/manganese nitride, iron/chromium nitride, and manganese gallium/manganese nitride. Two of these systems displayed an important magnetic coupling effect known in the magnetism field as exchange biasing, and in each case intriguing structural and/or magnetic phenomena were discovered at the interfaces or within the bi-layers, such as ordered atomic layer intermixing, perpendicular magnetic anisotropy, and the exchange spring effect.

Primarily, three Ph.D. students in experiment, two visiting Ph.D. students in theory, as well as 4 undergraduate students, participated in research under this award. Results from these studies have been detailed in 5 publications to date, with another 4 publications to be completed, 8 conference presentations, and 2 Ph.D. dissertations. One Ph.D. student won two prestigious national level awards at the Annual Symposium of the American Vacuum Society - the Leo M. Falicov student award for research in the area of magnetic interfaces and nanostructures, and the Russell and Sigurd Varian award which is the Society’s highest student award.

The project also involved science outreach to K-12 students through a program known as Science Investigators. Small groups of highly motivated 5th/6th and 7th/8th graders were engaged in hands-on science activities within modules which were done as after school activities as well as weekend activities. These elementary and middle school students were guided by top Ohio University physics undergraduates who also gained valuable teaching experience. Several of the hands-on activities were also included within the Physics and Astronomy Department’s biennial day-long Open House event which draws 900-1000 children and adults from the local community. The Science Investigators program was successful in generating enthusiasm for, and increasing interest in, science activities based on surveys and unsolicited comments that were received.

Overall, the project has led to a greater understanding of the intricacies involved in magnetic thin film bi-layer systems and has laid the foundations for future studies which will allow direct atomic-scale magnetic investigations of magnetic surfaces and interfaces using the advanced technique of spin-polarized STM. Scientific training of students at both the graduate and undergraduate levels was accomplished, and these students are well positioned for careers in science and industry. Science outreach has furthermore led to increased enthusiasm and appreciation for science within the local community.
